abstract: Once again overhauling the home page seen by its users, Facebook takes a step back from the live Web and aims to present a more selective batch of information.
snippet: Once again overhauling the home page seen by its users, Facebook takes a step back from the live Web and aims to present a more selective batch of information.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Facebook began introducing changes to its primary home page, which its 300 million members land on when they log on to the social network. Now, instead of the live feed of their friends’ status updates and activities, which had come to resemble the chaotic, hive-mind buzz of the Twittersphere, Facebook users now get a “news feed” — essentially the most significant and most-commented-on status updates and activities from their contacts in the last day.

headline.main: What Do You Think of Facebook’s Latest Changes?
